transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Hello, and thank you for having me. I'm happy to be here and share my experiences. Please go ahead with your questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Sure! As I mentioned, my name is Ava, and I'm a 40-year-old graphic designer living in suburban Portland. I have a bachelor's degree and work part-time, which gives me a bit of flexibility in my schedule. I'm single and have access to good healthcare through my employer's insurance, which I really appreciate. I'm generally health-conscious, though I admit I don’t exercise as regularly as I should. I manage generalized anxiety disorder with medication, which helps me stay balanced. I have one child from an uncomplicated vaginal delivery eight years ago, and I also had an elective abortion five years ago. At this point, I'm not planning on having any more children, and I use an intrauterine device for contraception. That pretty much sums up my current life situation!

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I found out I was pregnant for the first time about nine years ago. I remember taking a home pregnancy test after noticing that my period was late, and I was both excited and nervous at the same time. It was a bit of a surprise, but I ultimately decided to go through with the pregnancy. My first pregnancy was quite smooth, and I was able to have an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. It was a beautiful experience for me, and I really felt supported throughout that time.

As for my second pregnancy, I learned about it about five years ago. I found myself in a situation where I had to make a tough decision. After much consideration, I chose to have an elective abortion. It was a difficult choice, but I felt it was the right one for me at that time. I think it's important to have control over one's reproductive choices, and I'm grateful for the access I had to the necessary healthcare.

Do you want me to elaborate more on any specific aspects of my pregnancies?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first sought prenatal care shortly after I confirmed my pregnancy with my first child. I made an appointment with my healthcare provider as soon as I had the positive test result. The experience was quite positive overall. My provider was very supportive and took the time to answer all my questions, which made me feel more at ease. They explained the various tests and screenings that would be done throughout the pregnancy, and I appreciated the emphasis on both my physical health and emotional well-being.

I attended regular check-ups, and I found them to be reassuring. It was nice to hear the baby's heartbeat and see the ultrasounds. The staff was friendly, and I felt comfortable discussing any concerns I had. I was also given information about nutrition, exercise, and preparing for labor, which I found very helpful.

For my second pregnancy, I didn’t seek prenatal care because I ultimately decided on the elective abortion. I think if I had chosen to continue with that pregnancy, I would have approached my healthcare provider in a similar manner as I did the first time. 

Would you like to know more about specific aspects of my prenatal care, like the types of support I received or any challenges I faced?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Currently, I don't have a healthcare provider for prenatal care since I'm not planning on having another pregnancy. However, I can share my experiences with my healthcare providers from my previous pregnancy. During my first pregnancy, I was seeing an obstetrician in a local clinic. I had a great relationship with my provider—she was very approachable and understanding. I felt comfortable asking her questions, whether they were about my physical health or my emotional well-being.

She was very attentive during my visits, which made me feel valued and supported. I appreciated how she always took the time to explain any procedures or tests and encouraged me to voice any concerns I had. The communication was open, and I felt like I was truly part of the decision-making process regarding my care.

If I were to have another pregnancy, I would definitely seek out a similar provider—someone who prioritizes both my health and my feelings throughout the process. Would you like to ask about any specific interactions or experiences I had with healthcare providers during my first pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Since I’m not currently expecting, I can only reflect on my experience during my first pregnancy. During that time, I had prenatal appointments every four weeks during the first trimester, then they increased to every two weeks as I entered my third trimester, and finally, weekly visits as my due date approached. 

A typical visit would start with checking in at the front desk, where the staff was always friendly and welcoming. After that, I would go into the exam room, where a nurse would take my vital signs—like my blood pressure and weight—and ask about any concerns I might have. It was nice to have that one-on-one time to discuss how I was feeling both physically and emotionally.

Then, I would meet with my obstetrician. She would often start by asking how I was doing and if I had any specific questions or issues. I loved that she was very thorough; she would listen carefully and address everything I brought up. We would review the results of any tests or screenings that had been done, and she would explain what to expect in the upcoming weeks of my pregnancy.

During the later appointments, we would listen to the baby's heartbeat and discuss any preparations I needed to consider for labor and delivery. I remember feeling reassured when I heard that heartbeat! Sometimes, we would also discuss nutrition and exercise, which helped me stay on track with a healthy lifestyle during my pregnancy.

Overall, I found the visits to be very informative and supportive. It felt like a collaborative effort between my provider and me, which was really important to me. If you want, I can share more about any specific aspects of those appointments or how they impacted my overall experience.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I was fortunate to have an uncomplicated experience with no major health concerns or complications. I felt generally healthy throughout, which I believe contributed to the smooth delivery. I did have some typical discomforts, like back pain and occasional fatigue, but nothing that was alarming or required intervention.

I had regular check-ups, and my healthcare provider monitored my health closely, which helped me feel at ease. I also made sure to follow the recommended guidelines for nutrition and exercise, which I think played a role in my overall well-being during that time.

In terms of my second pregnancy, since I decided on an elective abortion, I didn't experience any pregnancy-related health concerns associated with that. However, it was an emotionally challenging decision, and I did seek support to navigate those feelings. 

If you'd like, I can discuss how my mental health, particularly my generalized anxiety disorder, impacted my pregnancies or any specific strategies I used to cope during those times. Would you like to explore that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I currently take medication for my generalized anxiety disorder, which helps me manage my anxiety levels and maintain a sense of stability in my daily life. I don’t have the exact name of the medication off the top of my head, but it's a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that my healthcare provider prescribed. 

In addition to my anxiety medication, I also take a daily multivitamin to ensure I’m getting the necessary nutrients, especially since I've become more health-conscious in recent years. I also try to incorporate omega-3 supplements into my routine, as I’ve read they can have benefits for both mental and physical health.

During my first pregnancy, I was careful about what I was taking and discussed all my medications with my healthcare provider to ensure they were safe for pregnancy. I stopped taking certain supplements and adjusted my medication under her guidance. I think it's so important to have open communication with your healthcare provider about any medications or supplements, especially during pregnancy.

If you want, I can share more about how my healthcare provider guided me regarding medications during my pregnancy or any concerns I had about taking my anxiety medication while expecting. Would you like to hear more about that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I made a conscious effort to focus on my diet and nutrition. I wanted to ensure that I was providing the best possible environment for my baby to grow and develop. I aimed to eat a well-balanced diet that included a variety of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. 

I remember being particularly mindful of my intake of folic acid, as I knew it was important for fetal development. I incorporated foods like leafy greens, beans, and fortified cereals into my meals. I also made sure to drink plenty of water to stay hydrated, which is so important during pregnancy.

My healthcare provider provided me with guidance on nutrition, and I appreciated the resources she offered. For example, she helped me understand which foods to avoid, such as certain types of fish high in mercury and unpasteurized dairy products. I also learned about how to manage cravings and balance indulgent foods with healthier options.

Additionally, I was careful about portion sizes and tried to listen to my body’s hunger cues. There were days when I had more cravings, especially for snacks, and I allowed myself some flexibility to enjoy those treats in moderation. Overall, I felt that maintaining a nutritious diet played a significant role in my overall well-being during pregnancy.

If you're interested, I can elaborate on any specific dietary practices I followed or how I balanced my nutrition with managing my anxiety during that time. Would you like to know more about that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I experienced a mix of emotions, which I think is quite common. Initially, I felt excited and hopeful, but there were also moments of anxiety and uncertainty, especially as I was navigating the changes in my body and life. I had a support system of friends and family who were very encouraging, which helped me a lot.

I was mindful of my mental health, especially since I have generalized anxiety disorder. I made it a priority to communicate with my healthcare provider about how I was feeling emotionally. She was very supportive and offered resources to help me manage any anxiety I experienced. I found that attending regular prenatal appointments was reassuring, as the consistent check-ins helped me feel more connected to the pregnancy and my healthcare team.

There were certainly days when I felt overwhelmed—especially as I approached the later stages of pregnancy and prepared for labor and delivery. However, I tried to practice mindfulness techniques, like deep breathing and meditation, which I had learned through therapy. These strategies helped me center myself and manage those anxious moments.

Overall, I would say that while my emotional journey during pregnancy had its ups and downs, I felt supported and empowered throughout the process. If you're interested, I could share more about specific coping strategies I used or how my mental health impacted my experience during different stages of the pregnancy. Would you like to know more about that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I had a solid support network that really made a difference in my experience. My family and close friends were incredibly supportive, and I felt fortunate to have them by my side. My parents were particularly excited about becoming grandparents, and they offered to help out in any way they could, whether it was attending appointments with me or just being there to listen.

I had a few close friends who had gone through pregnancy themselves, and they were wonderful sources of advice and encouragement. We would often chat about our experiences, and it was comforting to know that I wasn’t alone in navigating this journey. They were also there for me during moments of anxiety, reassuring me that it was normal to feel a bit overwhelmed.

In addition to my family and friends, I found support through my healthcare provider. As I mentioned earlier, she was very approachable and understanding, which helped me feel comfortable discussing my emotions and concerns. I also attended a prenatal class, where I met other expectant mothers. It was nice to connect with them and share our experiences and feelings, which further expanded my support network.

Overall, knowing that I had people to lean on made a significant difference in how I felt emotionally during my pregnancy. I think having a support system is crucial, especially when dealing with the ups and downs of pregnancy. If you're interested, I can share more about specific instances where my support network helped me or how I balanced those relationships with managing my anxiety. Would you like to know more about that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I did put some thought into my birth plan, and I communicated my preferences with my healthcare provider. I wanted to have an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, and I felt confident in my ability to do so based on my previous experiences and my provider's guidance.

I was interested in having a calm and supportive environment during labor. I expressed a desire to have my partner—who was my significant other at the time—present with me for support. I also wanted to utilize techniques like breathing exercises and movement to help manage pain during labor. I had prepared myself with some knowledge from prenatal classes, which provided me with various coping strategies.

I was open to the idea of pain relief options, but I wanted to wait and see how I felt during labor before making any decisions about epidurals or medications. My goal was to remain flexible, as I understood that the birth process can be unpredictable. I appreciated that my healthcare provider was supportive of my preferences and made it clear that we could adapt the plan as needed.

After discussing my birth plan with my provider and attending prenatal classes, I felt more prepared for the experience. It was reassuring to know that I had a team that would respect my wishes while also prioritizing the health and safety of both me and my baby.

If you'd like, I can share more about how my preferences influenced my experience during labor or how I felt about the actual delivery process. Would you like to explore that further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I sought out various sources of information to help me prepare for the experience of pregnancy and childbirth. I wanted to be as informed as possible, so I used a mix of resources.

Firstly, I read several books on pregnancy and childbirth. Some of my favorites included "What to Expect When You're Expecting" and "The Birth Partner." These books provided me with a comprehensive overview of what to expect during each trimester, as well as information on labor and delivery. I appreciated the practical advice and tips they offered, which helped me feel more prepared.

I also attended prenatal classes, which I found incredibly valuable. The classes covered a range of topics, including childbirth techniques, breastfeeding, and newborn care. It was great to learn in a group setting, as I was able to connect with other expectant parents and share experiences. The instructors were knowledgeable and provided hands-on demonstrations, which helped reinforce what I was learning.

In addition to books and classes, I relied on my healthcare provider for information. She was an excellent resource and always took the time to answer my questions. I felt comfortable discussing any concerns or uncertainties I had, and she provided me with evidence-based information tailored to my specific situation.

I also turned to online resources, such as reputable websites and forums for expectant parents. I made sure to choose sites that were reliable and backed by medical professionals. However, I was cautious about information found on social media, as I knew it could sometimes be misleading.

Overall, I found a combination of books, classes, healthcare provider guidance, and reputable online resources to be helpful in preparing me for my pregnancy and childbirth. If you'd like, I can share more about specific resources I found particularly beneficial or how I balanced the information I received with my own intuition and feelings during the process. Would you like to explore that?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I was fortunate to have good healthcare coverage through my employer's insurance, which significantly eased my financial concerns. I was able to access prenatal care without worrying too much about the costs, which was a relief. My insurance covered regular check-ups, necessary tests, and even some of the childbirth classes I attended.

I did create a budget to prepare for the baby’s arrival, taking into account expenses for essentials like a crib, baby clothes, diapers, and other necessities. I also considered potential costs for things like childcare, which I knew would be a significant expense once I returned to work. I did some research and compared prices to find the best deals, and I was fortunate to receive hand-me-downs from friends and family, which helped reduce costs.

I also looked into setting up a savings account specifically for baby-related expenses, which I found helpful in keeping my finances organized. I tried to plan for any unexpected costs as well, knowing that babies can bring surprises! 

Overall, while there were certainly financial considerations, my good insurance coverage and careful planning helped me feel more secure. If you'd like, I can share more about specific strategies I used to manage these financial aspects or how I balanced budgeting with other preparations for the baby. Would you like to explore that further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I was working part-time as a graphic designer, which allowed me some flexibility in my schedule. I found that my work situation was generally accommodating, which made a big difference in how I felt during that time. I was upfront with my employer about my pregnancy as soon as I felt comfortable sharing the news. Thankfully, they were very supportive and understanding.

Since I was only part-time, I was able to manage my workload fairly well, but I did notice that I sometimes had to take breaks or modify how I worked, especially as I got further along and experienced some fatigue and discomfort. My employer allowed me to adjust my hours as needed, which really helped. I also took advantage of the flexibility to attend prenatal appointments without too much stress.

I did feel some anxiety about how my pregnancy might impact my job, especially with the upcoming maternity leave. I wanted to make sure I was meeting expectations and contributing to the team, but I also recognized the need to prioritize my health and well-being. I communicated openly with my supervisor, and we discussed a plan for my leave. They were very understanding and assured me that they would support my transition back to work after the baby arrived.

Overall, I felt fortunate to be in a work environment that was supportive of my pregnancy. If you’d like, I can share more about specific conversations I had with my employer or how I balanced my work responsibilities with preparing for the baby. Would you like to explore that further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I did think quite a bit about the postpartum period and what it would mean for me. I knew that this time would come with its own set of challenges and adjustments, so I wanted to be as prepared as possible.

One of my primary concerns was about managing my mental health after the baby arrived, especially since I have generalized anxiety disorder. I was aware that the postpartum period could bring about a range of emotions, including potential feelings of anxiety and depression. To prepare for this, I planned to maintain open communication with my healthcare provider about any emotional struggles I might face. I also considered reaching out to a therapist if I felt I needed additional support.

I also thought about practical aspects, such as arranging for help during the early weeks after the baby was born. I discussed this with my parents and close friends, and they were more than willing to lend a hand, whether it was cooking meals, helping with household chores, or just providing companionship. I knew that having that support network in place would be crucial for my recovery and adjustment to motherhood.

In terms of physical recovery, I learned about what to expect after delivery, including the importance of self-care and rest. I intended to prioritize my recovery and not hesitate to ask for help when needed. I also planned to educate myself about newborn care, as I wanted to feel confident in managing those early days with a new baby.

Additionally, I considered how I would balance my work and parenting responsibilities once my maternity leave ended. I wanted to create a flexible plan that would allow me to transition back to work while also being present for my child. I felt it was important to have a clear understanding with my employer about my return and any arrangements for childcare.

Overall, I aimed to prepare for the postpartum period by focusing on both my mental and physical health, seeking support, and planning practically for the changes ahead. If you're interested, I can share more about specific resources I researched for postpartum care or how I planned to navigate the transition back to work. Would you like to explore that further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
